results.headline: Shirtless Cadets as Shakespeare’s Ill-Fated Young Lovers

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Private Romeo

results.summary_short: The director Alan Brown redirects the “Romeo and Juliet” narrative from interfamily rivalry to intrainstitutional homophobia.

results.headline: Coming Home, When Home No Longer Seems the Same

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Return

results.summary_short: Liza Johnson’s sober feature film debut, about a soldier returning from overseas duty, is a study of depression in a depressed environment.

results.headline: Can Amnesia Block the Path of Romance? Forget About It

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Vow

results.summary_short: In a romantic tale, Rachel McAdams plays an artsy young wife happily married until a car accident sends her into a coma from which she emerges with amnesia.

results.headline: Smoldering Superagent Runs...and Keeps on Running

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Safe House

results.summary_short: In this story about the bad, bad things that agents sometimes do in the name of country and company, Denzel Washington is put through his action-flick paces.

results.headline: Volcanic Adventures in Jules Verne Country

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Journey 2: The Mysterious Island 3D

results.summary_short: Another island goes kablooey in this sequel to the film “Journey to the Center of the Earth,” which again gives a Jules Verne tale a 3-D treatment.

results.headline: A Pianist and a Honey-Throated Chanteuse in the Heart of Havana

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Chico & Rita

results.summary_short: The fictional couple in this animated film about Cuba and its music mingle with real-life legends like Dizzy Gillespie, Thelonius Monk and Chano Pozo.

results.headline: An Industry Beneath the Surface

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Miners' Hymns

results.summary_short: Bill Morrison’s documentary uses found footage to recall the days when coal fueled Britain and to recount the demise of the mining trade.

results.headline: Turbines in the Backyard: The Sound and the Strobes

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Windfall

results.summary_short: The documentary “Windfall” shows the bitter rancor sowed among the residents of rural Meredith, N.Y., when the wind turbines came to town.

results.headline: Diamonds? The Stage Is This Girl’s Best Friend

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Carol Channing: Larger Than Life

results.summary_short: “Carol Channing: Larger Than Life,” a documentary by Dori Berinstein, chronicles the career of that theatrical clown “with huge saucer eyes, gigantic red lips and a massive smile.”

results.headline: A Haunted Lawyer? What Could Be Scarier?

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Woman in Black

results.summary_short: “The Woman in Black,” starring Daniel Radcliffe, isn’t especially scary, but it keeps you on edge, and without the usual vivisectionist imagery.

results.headline: Capturing (on Webcam) the Ghost Checked Into the Haunted Hotel

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Innkeepers

results.summary_short: During the final weekend at a New England inn, two employees capture ghostly images and haunting sounds on their cellphones and webcams.

results.headline: Riding the Waves and Life’s Woes

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Splinters

results.summary_short: In the documentary “Splinters” competition surfers skim the waves off Papua New Guinea while being weighed down by personal problems back in their village.

results.headline: Meet Wally & Wallis, Buddies Across Time

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of W.E.

results.summary_short: “W.E.,” Madonna’s film about Wallis Simpson also time-travels to the almost-present to tell the story of a bored New York housewife intrigued by Mrs. Simpson.

results.headline: A Hit Man Finds Himself Stalked by Evil

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Kill List

results.summary_short: Evil stalks two hit men at loose ends in “Kill List,” which delves into horror, psychodrama and religious rot.

results.headline: A Strange Epidemic Complicates an Already Complicated Love Story

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Perfect Sense

results.summary_short: In David Mackenzie’s “Perfect Sense,” a chef and an epidemiologist find love as an epidemic sweeps the planet, slowly depriving human beings of one sense after another.

results.headline: Escaping a Dark Home Down a Dark Hole

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Chronicle

results.summary_short: In Josh Trank’s “Chronicle,” three teenage boys inexplicably acquire extraordinary powers.

results.headline: Saving Whales While Melting Hearts and a Cold War

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Big Miracle

results.summary_short: Unlikely allies find themselves working together to save three whales trapped in ice in Alaska in “Big Miracle.”

results.headline: Striving for Comedy, a Loner Shuffles Toward Tragedy

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of Bad Fever

results.summary_short: In “Bad Fever” the painfully awkward hero longs for a career in comedy, though it’s clear from the outset that his real gift is for tragedy.

results.headline: Oh, Look, It’s Time Again for the Village Orgy

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of The Wicker Tree

results.summary_short: “The Wicker Tree,” directed by Robin Hardy, is a sort of companion piece to Mr. Hardy’s 1973 “The Wicker Man” (not to be confused with Nicolas Cage’s version).

results.headline: A Girl’s Got to Work: From Lingerie to Glocks

link.suggested_link_text: Read the New York Times Review of One for the Money

results.summary_short: Katherine Heigl plays a Trenton bounty hunter in “One for the Money,” a film adaptation of a best-selling novel by Janet Evanovich.
